docs.title: RAG Notes
docs.text:
Write notes in text files. Turn them into a website. Host it free.

This site is organized into two main guides:

  • Notes Site Setup: Learn how to build a documentation site like this one from scratch.
  • LightRAG Server Guide: A step-by-step tutorial for turning LightRAG into a native Mac application.

docs.title: 1. What is Zoxide?
docs.text: Zoxide is a "smarter cd command" for your shell. It remembers the directories you use most frequently, allowing you to jump to them in just a few keystrokes.

docs.title: The Problem with cd
docs.text:
The standard cd (change directory) command is fundamental, but it can be inefficient. To navigate to a deeply nested directory, you have to type out the full path or cd your way through each parent directory.

For example, to get to our project directory, you might type:

cd /Users/myuser/RAGprojects/rag-notes

If you're in a different location, you have to remember and type this entire path every time.

docs.title: How Zoxide Solves It
docs.text:
Zoxide runs in the background and keeps a ranked list of the directories you visit. Once it has "learned" your habits, you can jump to a directory by typing z followed by a part of the directory's name.

Instead of the long cd command above, you could simply type:

z rag

Or z notes, or z ragnotes. Zoxide is smart enough to figure out which directory you mean and take you there instantly.

It's a major productivity boost for anyone who spends a lot of time in the terminal.

Next: 2. Installation

docs.title: 2. Zoxide Installation
docs.text: This guide covers installing zoxide on macOS.

docs.title: Step 1: Install with Homebrew
docs.text:
The simplest way to install zoxide is with Homebrew, the standard package manager for macOS.

To use zoxide's interactive search feature (which we highly recommend), you also need to install fzf.

  1. Open your terminal.
  2. Run the install command: sh brew install zoxide fzf This will download and install both programs.

docs.title: Step 2: Hook Zoxide into Your Shell
docs.text:
For zoxide to work, it needs to be "hooked" into your shell. This allows it to track the directories you cd into.

  1. Open your shell's configuration file. This is most likely ~/.zshrc if you're on a modern version of macOS. sh open -e ~/.zshrc

  2. Add the initialization script. Add the following block to the very end of the file. This line runs the zoxide init command every time you start a new shell session.

    Warning: If TextEdit opens, be careful! Sometimes macOS automatically converts standard straight quotes (") into curly "Smart Quotes" (“ or ”). Ensure the quotes in the command below remain exactly as shown.

    ```sh

  3. Apply the changes. Save the file, and then either open a brand new terminal window or run the following command to apply the changes to your current session: sh source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Enables zoxide, a smarter cd command.
docs.text: eval "$(zoxide init zsh)"

docs.title: Step 3: Verify the Installation
docs.text:
You can check that zoxide is working by typing:

zoxide --version

If it prints a version number, the installation was successful.

zoxide will now start learning from your navigation habits. To build up its database, just cd around to your most-used project directories a few times.

Next: 3. Basic Usage

docs.title: 3. Basic Zoxide Usage
docs.text:
Once zoxide is installed and has learned your directory habits, you can start using it to navigate.

The main command is z.

docs.title: Jumping to a Directory
docs.text:
Instead of cd, use z followed by a keyword from the directory path you want to go to.

Let's say you've previously visited /Users/myuser/RAGprojects/rag-notes. You can now jump to it from anywhere by typing:

# Any of these will work
z rag
z notes
z ragnotes

Zoxide will find the best match and take you there.

docs.title: Interactive Search
docs.text:
If zoxide isn't sure where you want to go, or if you just want to see a list of choices, you can use the interactive search feature (this requires fzf to be installed).

Instead of z, you use the zi (z-interactive) command.

  1. Type zi followed by a query and press <Enter>. sh zi proj

  2. Use the arrow keys or type more letters to filter and select a directory from the list that appears. > /Users/myuser/RAGprojects/ /Users/myuser/other-projects/

  3. Press <Enter> to jump to the selected directory.

This is extremely useful when you have multiple directories with similar names.

docs.title: How Zoxide Ranks Directories
docs.text: Zoxide uses a ranking algorithm based on "frecency" — a combination of frequency and recency. This means it prioritizes directories that you visit often and have visited recently, which usually aligns with your current projects.

docs.title: Forcing a Directory to be Added
docs.text:
If you want to make sure a directory is added to zoxide's database without having to cd into it, you can use the zoxide add command:

zoxide add /path/to/important/directory

This ensures it's available for future queries.

docs.title: 1. Introduction to the LightRAG Server App
docs.text: This guide will walk you through turning LightRAG into a native-like Mac application that you can double-click to run.

docs.title: What You'll Achieve
docs.text:
By the end of this guide, you will have:

  • A standalone Mac application that starts a local RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) server.
  • A simple, double-click workflow to start and stop your personal AI server.
  • A system that works with either a free, local AI model (via Ollama) or a powerful cloud model (like OpenAI, Google Gemini, or Anthropic Claude).

docs.title: Before You Start: Prerequisites
docs.text:
You must have the following software installed on your Mac before you begin:

  1. An AI Provider:

    • For Local AI (Recommended): Ollama allows you to run models like Llama 3, Mistral, and Gemma directly on your machine for free.
    • For Cloud AI: Alternatively, you'll need an API key from a provider like OpenAI, Google AI, or Anthropic.

  2. Platypus Application:

    • Platypus is a free developer tool that turns scripts into Mac apps.
    • Download Platypus here. After downloading the .zip, open it and move the Platypus.app to your /Applications folder.

Once you have these ready, you can proceed to the next step.

Next: 2. Installation

docs.title: 2. LightRAG Installation
docs.text: This step covers installing the LightRAG command-line tool using uv.

docs.title: Step 1: Open Your Terminal
docs.text: You'll be running commands in the Mac Terminal app. - Press ⌘ + Space to open Spotlight. - Type Terminal and press Enter.

docs.title: Step 2: Install the LightRAG Tool
docs.text:
We will use uv, a fast Python package manager, to install lightrag-server as a global command-line tool. This means you can run it from anywhere on your system.

  1. Copy and paste the command below into your Terminal and press Enter: bash uv tool install "lightrag-hku[offline,observability]"

    • This command installs LightRAG with optional dependencies for offline models (offline) and server monitoring (observability).
    • The installation process will take a minute or two as it downloads and installs all the required packages.

  2. Wait for the installation to complete. You will see output in your terminal. A successful installation will end with a message similar to "Installed 103 packages".

docs.title: Step 3: Verify the Installation
docs.text:
To confirm that lightrag-server was installed correctly, you can check where the command is located.

  1. Run this command in your Terminal: bash which lightrag-server

  2. The output should look something like this: /Users/yourusername/.local/bin/lightrag-server (Where yourusername is your Mac username.)

If you see this path, the installation was successful and you're ready to set up the configuration.

Next: 3. Configuration

docs.title: 3. Server Configuration
docs.text: Now that LightRAG is installed, we need to create the necessary folders, a launcher script, and a configuration file to store your settings.

docs.title: Step 1: Create Project Folders
docs.text:
We will create a central folder in your home directory to hold all the server's files, including its data and your input documents.

  1. Open Finder. (Click the icon in your dock).
  2. Go to your Home folder: Press ⌘ + Shift + H.
  3. Create the main folder:
    • Press ⌘ + Shift + N to create a new folder.
    • Name it LightRAG.
  4. Create the inputs folder:
    • Go inside the new LightRAG folder.
    • Create another new folder and name it inputs.

You should now have this structure: - ~/LightRAG/ - This will be the server's working directory. - ~/LightRAG/inputs/ - This is where you will place the documents (PDFs, text files) you want the server to process.

docs.title: Step 2: Create the Launcher Script
docs.text:
This script is a small wrapper that tells the system where to find and how to run the lightrag-server command. Platypus will use this script to create the app.

  1. Open the Terminal app.

  2. Copy and paste the entire code block below into your terminal, then press Enter. This will create and save the script in one go.

    ```bash cat > ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh << 'EOF'

  3. Make the script executable: After creating the script, you need to give it permission to run. Execute this command in your terminal: bash chmod +x ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh

docs.title: Wrapper script for use with Platypus.app
Ensure the uv tool bin directory is in the PATH
docs.text: export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

docs.title: Define the working directory where data and configs are stored
docs.text: WORKING_DIR="$HOME/LightRAG"

docs.title: Create the data directory if it doesn't exist
docs.text: mkdir -p "$WORKING_DIR"

docs.title: Change to the working directory so the .env file is found
docs.text:
cd "$WORKING_DIR"

echo "Starting LightRAG Server..." echo " Config: $WORKING_DIR/.env" echo " Data: $WORKING_DIR" echo "" echo "Loading configuration from .env file..." echo "Press Ctrl+C or Cmd+Q to stop the server" echo "----------------------------------------"

docs.title: Execute the server, using the working directory
All other settings are loaded automatically from the .env file
docs.text: exec lightrag-server --working-dir "$WORKING_DIR" EOF ```

docs.title: Step 3: Create the Configuration File (.env)
docs.text:
The .env file holds all the settings for your server, such as which AI model to use, where your data is stored, and your API keys.

  1. Go to your LightRAG folder in Finder.

  2. Create a new, empty text file named .env.

    • The dot at the beginning makes it a "hidden" file.
    • If your editor doesn't let you save files starting with a dot, save it as env.txt, then go to Finder, click the file, and rename it to .env. You may need to press ⌘ + Shift + . to see hidden files in Finder.

  3. Open the .env file in a plain text editor (like TextEdit, VS Code, or Cursor).

  4. Copy and paste the configuration templates below.

    • Important: You must include the "General Settings" block.
    • Then, choose ONE of the model provider options (e.g., "Option 1: Ollama") and add it to the file.

docs.title: General Settings (Required for all setups)
docs.text:
Replace yourusername with your actual Mac username. You can find it by running whoami in the Terminal.

# --- General Server Settings ---
HOST=127.0.0.1
PORT=8020
WEBUI_TITLE=My Personal RAG
WEBUI_DESCRIPTION=A private RAG system powered by LightRAG

# --- Directory Settings ---
# Make sure to replace 'yourusername' with your actual username
WORKING_DIR=/Users/yourusername/LightRAG
INPUT_DIR=/Users/yourusername/LightRAG/inputs

# --- Indexing Performance ---
MAX_ASYNC=4
MAX_PARALLEL_INSERT=2
CHUNK_SIZE=1200
CHUNK_OVERLAP_SIZE=100

docs.title: Option 1: Ollama (Free, Local)
docs.text:
Use this for a completely local setup with Ollama.

# --- Model Settings: OLLAMA ---
LLM_BINDING=ollama
LLM_BINDING_HOST=http://localhost:11434
LLM_MODEL=mistral-nemo:latest
OLLAMA_LLM_NUM_CTX=32768

EMBEDDING_BINDING=ollama
EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=http://localhost:11434
EMBEDDING_MODEL=bge-m3:latest
EMBEDDING_DIM=1024

docs.title: Option 2: OpenAI (Cloud)
docs.text:
Use this if you have an OpenAI API key.

# --- Model Settings: OPENAI ---
LLM_BINDING=openai
LLM_BINDING_HOST=https://api.openai.com/v1
LLM_MODEL=gpt-4o
LLM_BINDING_API_KEY=sk-your-api-key-here

EMBEDDING_BINDING=openai
EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=https://api.openai.com/v1
EMBEDDING_MODEL=text-embedding-3-large
EMBEDDING_BINDING_API_KEY=sk-your-api-key-here

docs.title: Option 3: Google Gemini (Cloud)
docs.text:
Use this if you have a Google AI API key.

# --- Model Settings: GEMINI ---
LLM_BINDING=gemini
LLM_MODEL=gemini-2.5-flash
LLM_BINDING_HOST=https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com
LLM_BINDING_API_KEY=your-gemini-api-key-here

EMBEDDING_BINDING=gemini
EMBEDDING_MODEL=gemini-embedding-001
EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com
EMBEDDING_BINDING_API_KEY=your-gemini-api-key-here
EMBEDDING_DIM=1536
  1. Save the .env file after you've added your chosen configuration.

Your server is now configured! The next step is to test it and turn it into a clickable application.

Next: 4. Creating the App

docs.title: 4. Creating the Mac App
docs.text: With the configuration in place, let's test the script and then bundle it into a user-friendly Mac application using Platypus.

docs.title: Step 1: Test the Launcher Script
docs.text:
Before creating the app, it's crucial to ensure the script runs correctly on its own.

  1. Open the Terminal app.

  2. Run the launcher script directly: bash ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh

  3. Check the output. You should see messages indicating that the server is starting, followed by: Starting LightRAG Server... Config: /Users/yourusername/LightRAG/.env Data: /Users/yourusername/LightRAG ... INFO: Uvicorn running on http://127.0.0.1:8020 (Press CTRL+C to quit)

  4. Verify in your browser. Open Safari or Chrome and navigate to http://127.0.0.1:8020. You should see the LightRAG web interface.

  5. Stop the server. Go back to the Terminal window and press Ctrl + C to shut down the server.

If the script ran without errors and you could access the web UI, you're ready to proceed. If not, refer to the Troubleshooting guide.

docs.title: Step 2: Create the App with Platypus
docs.text:
Now we'll use Platypus to wrap our lightrag-launcher.sh script into a .app bundle.

  1. Open Platypus.

    • Go to your /Applications folder and double-click Platypus.app.

  2. Configure the Platypus settings as follows:

    • App Name: LightRAG Server (Platypus will automatically add the .app extension)

    • Script Path: Click Select... and choose the script:

    • Navigate to your home folder (⌘ + Shift + H).
    • Open the LightRAG folder.

    • Select the lightrag-launcher.sh file and click Open.

    • Interface: Set this to Text Window. This will display the server's log output in a window when the app is running, which is useful for seeing its status.

    • Identifier: com.lightrag.server.app This is a unique name for the application, following a reverse-domain convention.

    • Author: (Optional) You can put your name here.

    • Version: (Optional) You can put 1.0 here.

    • Checkboxes (at the bottom): Ensure both are UNCHECKED.

    • Run script in background: Unchecked
    • Remain running after script exits: Unchecked

    Your Platypus window should look like this:

    (Image of the Platypus interface with the correct settings would go here if possible)

  3. Click the "Create App" button at the bottom of the window.

  4. Save the Application.

    • A save dialog will appear.
    • In the left sidebar, select your Applications folder.
    • Click the Create button.

docs.title: You're Done!
docs.text:
Congratulations! You have successfully created LightRAG Server.app. You can find it in your /Applications folder. You can now start and stop your RAG server just by double-clicking this app, without ever needing to open the terminal again.

Next: 5. Usage Guide

docs.title: 5. Usage Guide
docs.text: Your LightRAG Server.app is ready. Here’s how to use and manage it.

docs.title: To Start the Server:
docs.text:
1. Open your /Applications folder in Finder (⌘ + Shift + A).
  2. Double-click the LightRAG Server app.

A text window will appear, showing the server's startup log. Once you see the line Uvicorn running on http://127.0.0.1:8020, the server is ready.

docs.title: To Stop the Server:
docs.text:
• Click on the LightRAG Server app's window to bring it to the front.
  • Simply quit the application by pressing ⌘ + Q.
  • Alternatively, you can press Ctrl + C inside the app's window.

docs.title: Accessing the Web Interface
docs.text:
Once the server is running, you can access its features through your web browser.

  • Main Web UI: http://127.0.0.1:8020 This is where you can chat with your documents.

  • API Documentation: http://127.0.0.1:8020/docs This is an interactive API browser (Swagger UI) for advanced users who want to integrate with the server programmatically.

docs.title: Adding Documents for Processing
docs.text:
The server needs documents to provide answers from. You can add PDF, TXT, or MD files.

  1. Open your LightRAG folder in your home directory.
  2. Open the inputs folder inside it.
    • The full path is ~/LightRAG/inputs/.
  3. Drag and drop your files into the inputs folder.

After adding files, go to the web interface (http://127.0.0.1:8020) and use the "Build" or "Index" functionality to process them. This step makes their content searchable.

docs.title: Changing Server Settings
docs.text:
You don't need to recreate the app to change the settings. All configuration is managed in the .env file.

  1. Locate the .env file in your ~/LightRAG/ folder.

    • Can't see it? Files starting with a dot are hidden by default on macOS. In Finder, press ⌘ + Shift + . (the period key) to toggle visibility of hidden files.

  2. Open .env in a text editor (e.g., TextEdit).

  3. Make your changes. You can:

    • Switch to a different Ollama model.
    • Change the port number if 8020 is already in use.
    • Switch from Ollama to OpenAI by pasting in the OpenAI configuration and adding your API key.

  4. Save the .env file.

  5. Restart the server. For the changes to take effect, you must quit and restart the LightRAG Server.app.

Next: 6. Troubleshooting

docs.title: 6. Troubleshooting and Reference
docs.text: This page contains solutions to common problems, a summary of file locations, and a quick reference for common actions.

docs.title: App Won't Start or Quits Immediately
docs.text:
This usually means there's an error in the underlying script or configuration.

  1. Test the script directly: Open the Terminal app and run the script to see the actual error message: bash ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh

  2. Read the error message. Common errors include:

    • command not found: lightrag-server: The installation failed or ~/.local/bin is not in your PATH.

    • Solution: Re-run the installation command: bash uv tool install "lightrag-hku[offline,observability]"

    • No such file or directory: '/Users/yourname/LightRAG/.env': The configuration file is missing or in the wrong place.

    • Solution: Make sure ~/LightRAG/.env exists.

    • Address already in use or Port already in use: Another application is using the port number (e.g., 8020) that LightRAG wants to use.

    • Solution: Open ~/LightRAG/.env and change the PORT setting to a different number, like 8030 or 9000. Save the file and restart the app.

docs.title: Can't See the .env File in Finder
docs.text:
Files that start with a dot (.) are hidden by default on macOS.

  • Solution: In Finder, navigate to your ~/LightRAG/ folder and press ⌘ + Shift + . (Command + Shift + Period) to toggle the visibility of hidden files.

docs.title: Server Starts, but Browser Shows "Can't Connect"
docs.text:
1. Check the Port: Look at the server app's window. The startup message says which port it's using (e.g., Uvicorn running on http://127.0.0.1:8020). Make sure you are using this exact address and port in your browser.
  2. Check for Errors: Look for any error messages in the server window that might have appeared after startup.

docs.title: File Location Reference
docs.text:
Here's a summary of where all the important files for your server app are located:

Item Location Description The Mac App /Applications/LightRAG Server.app The application you double-click to start. Settings File ~/LightRAG/.env All configuration (models, ports, API keys). Server Data ~/LightRAG/ The main folder for vector stores and other data. Documents to Index ~/LightRAG/inputs/ Place your PDF and text files here. Launcher Script ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh The core script used by the Platypus app.

docs.title: Quick Action Reference
docs.text: Goal Action Start Server Double-click LightRAG Server.app in Applications. Stop Server Press ⌘ + Q in the app window. Access Web UI Open http://127.0.0.1:8020 in your browser. Change Settings Edit ~/LightRAG/.env and restart the app. Add Documents Drag files into the ~/LightRAG/inputs/ folder.

docs.title: Need More Help?
docs.text:
• LightRAG Project: For more about the underlying tool, visit the LightRAG GitHub Repository.
  • Platypus: For questions about the app creation tool, see the Platypus Website.

docs.title: 1. Initial Setup
docs.text: This guide shows you how to set up your own personal notes website from scratch.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• You need a command-line terminal. On Mac, use the built-in Terminal app.
  • You need uv, a fast Python package installer.

If you don't have uv, open your terminal and run:

curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

Follow the on-screen instructions to add uv to your shell's PATH.

docs.title: Step 1: Create the Project
docs.text:
Open your terminal and run these commands one by one.

  1. Create a main project folder and navigate into it: bash mkdir -p ~/RAGprojects && cd ~/RAGprojects

  2. Initialize a new project named rag-notes: This creates a virtual environment without any default packages. bash uv init rag-notes --no-package

  3. Navigate into your new project directory: bash cd rag-notes

  4. Install MkDocs and the Material Theme: This gives you the documentation generator and the website theme. bash uv add mkdocs mkdocs-material

  5. Create the basic MkDocs file structure: This command sets up the docs folder and mkdocs.yml configuration file. bash uv run mkdocs new .

docs.title: Step 2: Run the Local Server
docs.text:
To see your website locally, run the development server:

uv run mkdocs serve --livereload
  • --livereload automatically reloads the site when you save a file.

Open your web browser and go to http://127.0.0.1:8000. You should see the default MkDocs welcome page.

To stop the server, go back to your terminal and press Ctrl + C.

docs.title: Next Step
docs.text:
Now that your site is running locally, let's learn how to add and edit content.

Next: 2. Writing Content

docs.title: 2. Writing Content
docs.text: This guide explains how to add new pages (like this one) and organize your notes.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
• Your website's pages are just simple text files written in Markdown.
  • All your pages live inside the docs/ directory.
  • The navigation menu is defined in the mkdocs.yml file.

docs.title: Creating a New Page
docs.text:
1. Create a new file:

    • Go to the docs/ directory in your project.
    • Create a new file with a .md extension (e.g., my-new-note.md).

  2. Write your content:

    • Open the file in a text editor (like VS Code, Sublime Text, or even Notepad).
    • Write your notes using Markdown syntax.

    Example Markdown: ```markdown

docs.title: My New Note
docs.text:
This is a paragraph. You can use bold, italics, and code.

  • Create
  • bullet
  • lists ```

docs.title: Adding the Page to the Navigation
docs.text:
To make your new page appear in the site's navigation menu, you need to edit the mkdocs.yml file.

  1. Open mkdocs.yml: This file is in the root of your project.
  2. Find the nav: section: This is where the navigation structure is defined.
  3. Add your new page: Add a new entry to the list. The format is Page Title: path/to/your/file.md.

Example mkdocs.yml:

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - My First Note: my-first-note.md
  - My New Note: my-new-note.md  # <-- Add this line

Instantly see the change: If your local server is running (uv run mkdocs serve), your website will automatically update with the new page in the navigation.

docs.title: Creating Sub-sections
docs.text:
You can create nested navigation by adding a sub-list under a main item.

Example mkdocs.yml with sub-sections:

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Tutorials:
    - Git Basics: tutorials/git-basics.md
    - Python Tips: tutorials/python-tips.md
  • In this example, you would need to create a tutorials/ folder inside your docs/ directory.
  • Then, place git-basics.md and python-tips.md inside docs/tutorials/.

docs.title: Next Step
docs.text:
Once you've added your content, it's time to publish your site to the web.

Next: 3. Publishing Your Site

docs.title: 3. Publishing Your Site
docs.text: This guide covers how to save your work to GitHub and deploy it as a live website using GitHub Pages.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• You need a GitHub account.
  • You need the GitHub CLI (gh) installed.

docs.title: Step 1: Save Your Project to GitHub
docs.text:
These commands will initialize a Git repository, save your files, and upload them to a new GitHub repository.

Run these from the root of your rag-notes project directory.

  1. Initialize Git and add all your files: bash git init git add .

  2. Commit your files: This creates a snapshot of your project's current state. bash git commit -m "Initial commit"

  3. Create a new repository on GitHub and push your code: This command uses the GitHub CLI to create a new public repository named rag-notes, sets it as the origin remote, and pushes your committed files to it. bash gh repo create rag-notes --source=. --remote=origin --push --public

    Follow the prompts to authenticate if you haven't already.

docs.title: Step 2: Deploy the Site with GitHub Pages
docs.text:
Now that your code is on GitHub, you can deploy it with a single command.

  1. Run the gh-deploy command: This command, provided by mkdocs, builds the static HTML for your site and pushes it to a special gh-pages branch on your repository. bash uh uv run mkdocs gh-deploy

  2. Wait for the deployment: It can take a minute or two for GitHub Pages to build and deploy your site.

docs.title: Step 3: View Your Live Site
docs.text:
Your website will be available at:

https://YOUR-USERNAME.github.io/rag-notes/

(Replace YOUR-USERNAME with your actual GitHub username.)

docs.title: How to Update Your Site in the Future
docs.text:
Now that everything is set up, updating your site is a simple three-step process.

  1. Make your changes: Edit your Markdown files in the docs/ directory.

  2. Save and push your changes to GitHub: Run this command from your project root: bash git add . && git commit -m "Update notes" && git push (You can change the commit message "Update notes" to something descriptive.)

  3. Re-deploy to GitHub Pages: bash uv run mkdocs gh-deploy

That's it! Your changes will be live in a few minutes.
